title: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome
diagnosis_topic: Compression of neurovascular structures at the thoracic outlet
setup_script: A 29-year-old competitive swimmer experiences numbness and weakness in her right arm when training. Symptoms worsen with overhead activity and are accompanied by swelling and discoloration of the hand.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 118/70 mmHg, HR 72 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.8 C.
Positive Adson's and Roos tests reproducing symptoms; absent radial pulse when head turned to right; mild thenar atrophy.
Duplex ultrasound shows subclavian vein compression during provocative maneuvers; CTA demonstrates cervical rib and venous congestion.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders nerve conduction studies
dynamic_flow.reply: Reveal brachial plexus compression at thoracic outlet.
Recommend physical therapy focused on postural correction and first-rib mobilization; symptoms improve initially.
Indicated if acute effort thrombosis (Paget-Schroetter) occurs; not present now.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident refers to vascular surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Discuss first rib resection and scalenectomy for persisting neurovascular compromise.
Progressive neurologic deficits and venous thrombosis develop.
Avoid heavy overhead activities until definitive treatment.
Compression may involve brachial plexus, subclavian vein, or subclavian artery.
Overhead athletes, cervical ribs, repetitive trauma.
Physical therapy to restore range of motion and prevent recurrence.

critical_decision_points: Appropriate use of provocative maneuvers and imaging
Recognition of indications for surgical decompression
